name: Acadia National Park
funFact: Acadia was the first national park east of the Mississippi River, established in 1916.
description: Known for its rocky headlands and diverse habitats.

name: American Samoa National Park
funFact: The only U.S. national park south of the equator, covering three volcanic islands.
description: Features coral reefs, rainforests, and volcanic mountains.

name: Arches National Park
funFact: Home to over 2,000 natural stone arches, including the famous Delicate Arch.
description: Known for its iconic red rock formations and arches.

name: Badlands National Park
funFact: Contains one of the world's richest fossil beds, dating back 75 million years.
description: Features dramatic landscapes and layered rock formations.

name: Big Bend National Park
funFact: Named for the prominent bend in the Rio Grande River, it covers over 800,000 acres.
description: Known for its desert landscapes and river canyons.

name: Biscayne National Park
funFact: 95% of the park is water, protecting a portion of the Florida Reef, the only living coral barrier reef in the continental U.S.
description: Features coral reefs and islands.

name: Black Canyon of the Gunnison National Park
funFact: The canyon is so deep, narrow, and sheer that very little sunlight reaches the bottom, earning it the name 'Black Canyon'.
description: Known for its steep cliffs and dramatic vistas.

name: Bryce Canyon National Park
funFact: Bryce Canyon is famous for its unique rock formations called hoodoos, which are formed by frost weathering and stream erosion.
description: Features colorful spire-shaped rock formations.

name: Canyonlands National Park
funFact: The park is divided into four districts by the Green and Colorado Rivers: the Island in the Sky, the Needles, the Maze, and the rivers themselves.
description: Features vast canyons and river-carved landscapes.

name: Capitol Reef National Park
funFact: Named for the white domes of Navajo Sandstone that resemble the U.S. Capitol building.
description: Features cliffs, canyons, and domes.

name: Carlsbad Caverns National Park
funFact: The park includes more than 119 caves, formed by sulfuric acid dissolution, with the Big Room being the largest accessible cave chamber in North America.
description: Known for its extensive cave system.

name: Channel Islands National Park
funFact: Home to over 2,000 species of plants and animals, 145 of which are found nowhere else in the world.
description: Features five remarkable islands and their ocean environment.

name: Congaree National Park
funFact: Home to the largest intact expanse of old growth bottomland hardwood forest in the southeastern U.S.
description: Features floodplain forests and diverse ecosystems.

name: Crater Lake National Park
funFact: Crater Lake is the deepest lake in the U.S., formed in the caldera of an ancient volcano, Mount Mazama.
description: Known for its deep blue color and water clarity.

name: Cuyahoga Valley National Park
funFact: The park's Towpath Trail follows the historic route of the Ohio & Erie Canal, which opened in 1827.
description: Features rolling hills, forests, and open farmlands.

name: Death Valley National Park
funFact: Death Valley is the hottest, driest, and lowest national park in the U.S., with Badwater Basin being 282 feet below sea level.
description: Known for its extreme temperatures and unique desert landscapes.

name: Denali National Park
funFact: Denali, formerly known as Mount McKinley, is the tallest peak in North America, standing at 20,310 feet.
description: Features majestic mountains and diverse wildlife.

name: Dry Tortugas National Park
funFact: Accessible only by boat or seaplane, the park is home to Fort Jefferson, one of the largest 19th-century forts in the U.S.
description: Features crystal-clear waters, coral reefs, and marine life.

name: Everglades National Park
funFact: The largest subtropical wilderness in the U.S., home to rare and endangered species like the manatee and the American crocodile.
description: Features vast wetlands and diverse wildlife.

name: Gates of the Arctic National Park
funFact: One of the last truly wild places on earth, with no roads or trails within the park.
description: Known for its remote wilderness and rugged mountains.

name: Gateway Arch National Park
funFact: The park commemorates the westward expansion of the United States and is home to the iconic 630-foot Gateway Arch.
description: Features the Gateway Arch, which is the tallest man-made monument in the U.S.

name: Glacier Bay National Park
funFact: The park features over 1,000 glaciers and one of the world’s largest protected ecosystems.
description: Known for its stunning glaciers and marine life.

name: Glacier National Park
funFact: Home to over 700 miles of hiking trails, Glacier National Park is part of the world's first International Peace Park.
description: Features rugged mountains and pristine forests.

name: Grand Canyon National Park
funFact: The Grand Canyon is one of the Seven Natural Wonders of the World and is over a mile deep.
description: Known for its immense size and colorful landscape.

name: Grand Teton National Park
funFact: The park includes the 40-mile-long Teton Range and the Snake River.
description: Features stunning mountain scenery and wildlife.

name: Great Basin National Park
funFact: Home to the ancient bristlecone pines, some of the oldest living trees on earth, and Lehman Caves.
description: Features diverse landscapes and stargazing opportunities.

name: Great Sand Dunes National Park
funFact: Home to the tallest sand dunes in North America, reaching heights of up to 750 feet.
description: Features vast sand dunes and mountain scenery.

name: Great Smoky Mountains National Park
funFact: The most visited national park in the U.S., with over 11 million visitors annually.
description: Known for its diverse plant and animal life.

name: Guadalupe Mountains National Park
funFact: Home to the four highest peaks in Texas, including Guadalupe Peak at 8,749 feet.
description: Features rugged mountains and desert terrain.

name: Haleakalā National Park
funFact: Named after the dormant Haleakalā Volcano, which last erupted over 400 years ago.
description: Known for its volcanic landscapes and sunrises.

name: Hawai'i Volcanoes National Park
funFact: Home to Kīlauea, one of the world’s most active volcanoes, and Mauna Loa, the world's largest volcano.
description: Features volcanic landscapes and lava flows.

name: Hot Springs National Park
funFact: The only national park with a town inside it, Hot Springs is famous for its thermal springs.
description: Features historic bathhouses and hot springs.

name: Indiana Dunes National Park
funFact: The park features 15 miles of the southern shore of Lake Michigan and diverse ecosystems.
description: Known for its sand dunes and beaches.

name: Isle Royale National Park
funFact: One of the least visited national parks, offering solitude and wilderness with no roads.
description: Features rugged, isolated islands and scenic wilderness.

name: Joshua Tree National Park
funFact: Named after the unique Joshua Trees, which are a species of yucca.
description: Known for its desert landscapes and rock formations.

name: Katmai National Park
funFact: Famous for the Valley of Ten Thousand Smokes, a volcanic ash flow from the 1912 eruption of Novarupta.
description: Features volcanic landscapes and brown bear viewing.

name: Kenai Fjords National Park
funFact: Home to the Harding Icefield, which feeds over 40 glaciers.
description: Known for its glaciers and marine wildlife.

name: Kings Canyon National Park
funFact: Contains the deepest canyon in the U.S., Kings Canyon, which is over a mile deep.
description: Features giant sequoias and deep valleys.

name: Kobuk Valley National Park
funFact: Home to the Great Kobuk Sand Dunes, the largest active sand dunes in the Arctic.
description: Known for its sand dunes and caribou migration.

name: Lake Clark National Park
funFact: Accessible only by boat or plane, Lake Clark offers pristine wilderness and volcanoes.
description: Features rugged mountains and turquoise lakes.

name: Lassen Volcanic National Park
funFact: One of the few places in the world where all four types of volcanoes can be found: shield, composite, cinder cone, and plug dome.
description: Known for its volcanic landscapes and geothermal features.

name: Mammoth Cave National Park
funFact: The world's longest known cave system, with more than 400 miles explored.
description: Features extensive underground passages and chambers.

name: Mesa Verde National Park
funFact: Preserves the largest collection of ancient cliff dwellings in North America, built by the Ancestral Puebloans.
description: Known for its archaeological sites and cliff dwellings.

name: Mount Rainier National Park
funFact: Mount Rainier is an active volcano and the most glaciated peak in the contiguous U.S.
description: Features meadows, old-growth forests, and glaciers.

name: North Cascades National Park
funFact: Contains over 300 glaciers, more than any other U.S. national park outside Alaska.
description: Known for its rugged mountains and alpine lakes.

name: Olympic National Park
funFact: Encompasses three distinct ecosystems: subalpine forest, temperate rain forest, and the Pacific coastline.
description: Features diverse landscapes from mountains to beaches.

name: Petrified Forest National Park
funFact: Contains one of the world's largest and most colorful concentrations of petrified wood.
description: Known for its fossils and desert landscapes.

name: Pinnacles National Park
funFact: The remains of an ancient volcanic field that eroded over millions of years.
description: Features rock formations, talus caves, and endangered condors.

name: Redwood National and State Parks
funFact: Home to some of the tallest trees on Earth, including Hyperion, which stands at 379 feet.
description: Known for its giant redwoods and coastal scenery.

name: Rocky Mountain National Park
funFact: Contains over 60 peaks higher than 12,000 feet, including Longs Peak at 14,259 feet.
description: Features rugged mountains and alpine tundra.

name: Saguaro National Park
funFact: Named for the iconic saguaro cactus, which can grow over 40 feet tall.
description: Known for its desert landscapes and cacti.

name: Sequoia National Park
funFact: Home to the General Sherman Tree, the largest tree on Earth by volume.
description: Features giant sequoias and mountain scenery.

name: Shenandoah National Park
funFact: Includes a portion of the Appalachian Trail, which runs for over 100 miles through the park.
description: Known for its scenic Skyline Drive and mountain views.

name: Theodore Roosevelt National Park
funFact: Named after the 26th President of the United States, who was a strong advocate for conservation.
description: Features badlands, prairie landscapes, and wildlife.

name: Virgin Islands National Park
funFact: Covers approximately 60% of the island of St. John and includes underwater areas.
description: Known for its beaches, coral reefs, and hiking trails.

name: Voyageurs National Park
funFact: Named after the French-Canadian fur traders known as 'voyageurs' who traveled the area in the 18th and 19th centuries.
description: Features interconnected waterways and forests.

name: Wind Cave National Park
funFact: Contains one of the world's longest and most complex cave systems.
description: Known for its unique boxwork formations and prairie landscapes.

name: Wrangell-St. Elias National Park
funFact: The largest national park in the U.S., covering an area larger than six Yellowstone National Parks.
description: Features mountains, glaciers, and wildlife.

name: Yellowstone National Park
funFact: The first national park in the world, established in 1872.
description: Known for its geothermal features, such as geysers and hot springs.

name: Yosemite National Park
funFact: Home to Yosemite Falls, one of the tallest waterfalls in North America.
description: Known for its granite cliffs, waterfalls, and giant sequoias.

name: Zion National Park
funFact: Known for the Zion Canyon, which is 15 miles long and up to 2,640 feet deep.
description: Features high plateaus, a labyrinth of narrow, deep sandstone canyons, and striking rock formations.
